Illustrations of fish, accompanied by the words ''fish,'' ''pescado,'' ''poisson'' and ''pesce,'' swim around the bottle of '98 Loire sauvignon blanc. On a '98 Gascon white, a chardonnay-colombard blend, the decoration is a fat bird with ''chicken,'' ''pollo,'' ''poulet.''

Illustrations of fish, accompanied by the words ''fish,'' ''pescado,'' ''poisson'' and ''pesce,'' swim around the bottle of '98 Loire sauvignon blanc. On a '98 Gascon white, a chardonnay-colombard blend, the decoration is a fat bird with ''chicken,'' ''pollo,'' ''poulet.''

One southern red (a '98 merlot-cabernet sauvignon combo) features a smiling steer with ''beef,'' ''boeuf,'' ''ternera.'' On another, a '98 cabernet-syrah blend, a sheep alternates with illustrations of chops: ''lamb,'' ''agnello,'' ''agnelet.''

The importer, Robert S. Mautner of Tri Vin, in Mount Vernon, N.Y., says these back-to-basics wines sell like gangbusters in European supermarkets, where they are sold as ''Beber y Comer,'' ''Trinken und Essen'' and ''Bere e Mangiare.''

All four appealing wines are three tweaks above vin ordinaire. The sauvignon is crisp and grapefruity; the chardonnay-colombard, a nippy thirst-slaker; the merlot-cabernet, robust and comfy; the cabernet-syrah, a chunky brew.

In Manhattan, various combinations can be found at SoHo Wines, 461 West Broadway (Houston Street), all $8, and at West 57th Street Wines, 344A%%cq%% West 57th (Eighth Avenue), all $8; in Brooklyn, Marlboro, 2317 Stillwell Avenue (Avenue M), in Bensonhurst, all $8; in Queens, Lowery's Wine Factory, 40-14 Queens Boulevard (40th Street), Sunnyside, all $7.
